Anyway, Major, why should he leave his country, his mother tongue, his family, his history, his past, his future, just because now, suddenly, there is a dictatorship? Why?
Colonel. He had no sisters, no brothers, only a lot of love affairs.
That's why he didn't get the hell out of here when he had the chance! I put that to him, he couldn't answer. Why didn't he go and direct in America, like that Italian, Toscanini.
A great artist will have great privileges in a Russian zone.
We're dealing with degenerates here.
Furtwngler's in a different category.

I was in Vienna. I had with me an Austrian chauffeur, Max his name was, he spent time in the camps. We were looking at these Viennese cleaning up the bomb damage, scavenging for rotting food, butt ends, anything. I said, 'To think a million of these people came out to welcome Adolf on the day he entered the city, a million of 'em, and now look at 'em.'  And Max said, 'Oh, not these people, Major. These people were all at home hiding Jews in their attics.' You get the point, Colonel? The point is they're all full of shit.
I've had two meetings with him. He's a great musician. Maybe the greatest conductor in the world. His Brahms, Beethoven, Schubert - unequalled.
Not yet.
So, Major, tell me, have you questioned Dr. Furtwngler?
Colonel. Pleasure.
Hello, Major, my name is Dymshitz. I'm glad to see you.
I would like to go now, please.
If he had no idea, why did the Jews need saving? This is the question, Emmi, to all Germans: Why did the Jews need saving in this country? Why, if people had no idea?
But he had no idea, a lot of people had no idea. I only realised what was really going on when I got arrested.
Emmi, stop! I want to show you something. Let me show you something and then if you want to leave, you can leave, please please. His friends, they did this. And he gave them birthday concerts.
I have been questioned by the Gestapo just like that. Just like you questioned him.
What's not right?
I can't do this. It's not right.
What is this, Emmi?
I'm sorry but I have to leave. I'll find other work. You'll have to get someone else, that's all.
Put it on ready to play, and I'll tell you when to play it.
Of course.
Do you know where the Adagio begins?
Bruckner's Seventh, Major.
Shut the door, Emmi. Sit down, Emmi. We're going to keep him waiting, too.
Major, Major... he's here ...
Come in, Emmi, this is your office, too. Emmi, this is Lieutenant David Wills.
I'm sorry.
You tell him nothing, Emmi. If he calls again, you say you know nothing. We're gonna keep him waiting while I get acquainted with his case and with the witnesses. And, God help me, with Beethoven.
The names of the members of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra since 1934 together with their questionnaires.  Major, what am I to tell Dr. Furtwngler?
What's in those files?
No. Ours was damaged.
I'm kidding, Emmi. What about a record player? You have that, too?
But... he only wrote nine, Major.
Mine's the Eleventh.
Oh yes, Major, I have recordings of all his symphonies. I kept them safe during the bombing. My favourite is the Seventh Symphony.
Think you can get me any of that?
There have been messages for you.  A Lieutenant David Wills called from the Allied Kommandatura Cultural Affairs office in Wiesbaden. I don't know who he is.
Steve.
And your father was executed.
Yes. She suffered longer. She was in Ravensbruck.
Your mother, too.
My father was one of the officers in the plot against Hitler. They arrested the plotters and their families.
Says here because of your father. What's that mean?
Three months.
Okay, let's see. How long were you in the camp for?
Yes.
You do shorthand and typing?
Yes.
You live here, in Berlin?
Look around you. See the country you served. Look at people who had real courage, who took risks, who risked their lives. Like Emmi's father.
I love my country, I believe in music, what was I to do?

Have you ever smelled burning flesh? I smelt it four miles away. Four miles away, I smelt it. Have you ever seen the gas chambers, the crematoria? Have you seen the mounds of rotting corpses? You talk to me about culture, art and music? You putting that in the scales, Wilhelm? You setting culture, art and music against the millions put to death by your pals? They had orchestras in the camps. They played Beethoven, Wagner. The hangmen were playing chamber music at home with their families. I don't understand the Germans' relationship with music. What do you need music for? Your pals you could call to save a few Jews when millions of them were being annihilated? Yes, I blame you for not getting hanged, I blame you for your cowardice. You strutted and swaggered, you fucking piece of shit, king-pin in a shithouse. You talk to me about walking a tightrope between exile and the gallows, and I say to you, lies!

I'll tell you, then. The last time this music was played on these air waves was after they announced that your pal Hitler had shot himself. Listen to it.  They listen. Did they pick little K's recording? Did they pick some other conductor? No, they picked you, and why? Because you represented them so beautifully. When the Devil died, they wanted his bandleader to conduct the funeral march. You were everything to them.
How can I know such a thing?
Who's conducting?
Bruckner's Seventh. The Adagio.
Okay, so what is it?
Of course I know what that is.
Do you know what that is?
Speaking to Party members I used their language, of course I did, everyone did.
I believe that. But just answer the question, don't give me explanations.
Those attitudes do not exist in me.

Everybody says what a great benefactor you were to the Jews. But--  I have things here you said and wrote. Listen to this: 'The Jew composer Schonberg is admired by the Jewish International.' And what about this: 'Jewish musicians lack a genuine affinity with our music.' 'Jewish musicians are good businessmen with few scruples, lacking roots.' You deny you said these things?
No, that's your problem, Wilhelm. You understand nothing. We'll call you. Go!
I don't understand what you mean.
Okay, Wilhelm, go home now. Go home and think about these past twelve years.
But you see what I'm getting at? You get a gorgeous house, you're highly paid. What are you gonna do, stay or leave? One voice comes back at me: stay!
I absolutely refused the house and the bomb shelter.
No, I'm not going to stop it. Hitler himself offered you a beautiful house and a personal bomb shelter.
Stop this, please, stop this now!
You like the women, don't you, Wilhelm?
I said I have illegitimate children. I don't know how many.
What?
I have illegitimate children.
Of course there was a conspiracy against me, a campaign - even abroad.

Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime?  Jealousy?
This is absolute nonsense!

Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book,  The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K.
Yes, that's what happened.
I'll tell you why. You remember we talked about you playing for Hitler's birthday?  And you told me that Goebbels got to your doctors first, that you were tricked?
Please stop playing these games with me. Why you should bring up the name of another conductor is beyond my understanding.
Now, that young conductor what's his name?  That miracle kid, you know who I mean. Von Karajan! But you called him something else. C'mon. What did you call von Karajan?
I'm sorry.
You've really no idea? I'll tell you what happened. He died in Stalingrad.
I have no idea.
And what happened to Von der Nul?
He said, 'Don't mind him. His job is to criticise, your job is to conduct.'
And what did he say?
Well. Once he said he'd read what this man wrote about me.

You sure you didn't call one of your close buddies and say, God in heaven, did you see what that guy von der Null wrote about me? The greatest conductor on earth. I want him out the way. He had the nerve to accuse me I am not playing enough modern music. Send him to Stalingrad. Isn't that what you did? You don't like criticism, do you, Wilhelm?  You surely didn't like them saying there was another conductor who was better than you... Are you saying the name von der Null was never mentioned in your talks with Goebbels?
That's an outrageous lie!

Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, Von Karajan, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better conductor than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since?
Yes, I know who he is.

How long's this going to go on, Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you say von der Null, I say von der Null, you say von der Null, we could go on all day. You know who von der Null is, don't you? Edwin von der Nuell, music critic.
Von der Null?
Yes, von der Null.
Von der Null?
Tell me about von der Null.
No, because I had only one intention. My only intention whatever I did was to show that music means more than politics.
No!
have no idea what ordinary people thought.

You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The Berlin Philharmonic's taken over by Doctor Goebbels and his Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought?
We never, never officially represented the regime when we played abroad. We always performed as a private ensemble. As I think I already told you, I was a freelance conductor.

Art and politics, yeah, art and politics. Let's look at that. You and the Berlin Philharmonic toured the Third Reich, played in countries the Nazis had conquered. Are you saying that conducting in occupied territories from 1939 on wasn't a commercial for Adolf and all he stood for?
Then you are wrong.

Well, I tried, you got to admit I tried. I thought I might just trap you there, Wilhelm, but David here was too quick for me. Smart move, David, smart move. No, I don't have the telegram, but I know it exists. And I want you to know, Wilhelm, we're going to keep looking for it because I believe you sent it.
You won't find it because no such telegram exists.
I don't have to think carefully. This is utterly ridiculous.
Think carefully, Wilhelm... maybe not in your own name, but as Privy Councillor or Vice-President.
I never sent him any birthday greetings or any other kind of greetings.
The birthday greetings you sent to your old pal, Adolf Hider.
I have no idea what you're talking about.

'Happy birthday, dear Adolf, love Wilhelm.' Or words to that effect. That sounds to me like you were dropping on your knees and saying, 'Okay, Adolf, you win. You're the number one man. Have a swell party.'
What telegram?
And when did you first learn that - when you sent the telegram? Was that the surrender signal, the waving of the white flag?
I believe art and politics should be separate, but that they weren't kept separate I learned to my cost.

Gee, that's a thing of beauty, honest to God, a real thing of beauty. I'm going to try to remember that. Liberty, humanity and justice. Beautiful. But you used the word 'naive'. Are you now saying you think you were wrong? That art and politics can't be separated?
Maintain liberty, humanity and justice.
And what was that?

When I last saw you, I was unprepared. I did not know what to expect. In these past weeks, I have been thinking more carefully and making some notes.  You have to understand who I am and what I am. I am a musician and I believe in music. I am an artist and I believe in art. Art in general, and music, in particular, has for me mystical powers which nurture man's spiritual needs. I must confess, however, to being extremely naive.  I insisted for many years on the absolute separation of art and politics. My entire life was devoted to music because, and this is very important, because I thought that I could, through music, do something practical.
Go ahead, be my guest.
I wish to say something.
If it's too hot, open your tie.
Don't talk to me like I was a second violinist. Go back into the waiting room. Miss Straube will come and get you when I am ready to see you.
It is now nine o'clock precisely. I do not intend to be kept waiting again.

Oh boy, you're gonna love this. Take your time with this now. Those files contain the details of every working artist in this country. Those files are gonna tell us who joined the Party, who informed and who was helpful.
He told me to be careful as one of Goebbels' men was watching me. He read a report on me - everything I said was quoted word by word.
What did Goering say?
Goering. Because Hinkel was working for Goebbels.
Who warned you?
I was warned.
How?
I wasn't told. I just knew it.
Who?
Certainly not, but I knew he had informers everywhere. Even in my orchestra there was someone
Yup, that's him, that's the guy. You know what else the little creep did? He kept files, close on 250,000 files. And you know what's in those files?
Yes, a despicable human being. He was in the Ministry of Culture. His job was to get rid of Jews in the arts.
I've got to hand it to the British, David. You know what those guys are?  Decent.  Tell me, Herr Dr. Furtwngler, do you know Hans Hinkel?
I've had enough of this, I'm leaving.
Steve Arnold...
See, David? He can't answer the question. I'll ask it again, Wilhelm, and don't give me any more airy-fairy, intellectual bullshit!
They were Jews, they had to leave. They were right to leave.  I could not leave my country in her deepest misery. After all, I am a German.  I... I stayed in my homeland. Is that my sin in your eyes?
I have a list of names here, people in your profession, who got out in '33. Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer, Arnold Schoenberg, Max Reinhardt...
If you are going to bully me like this, Major, you had better do your homework. You obviously have no idea how impertinent and stupid your questions are.
You were real close to all of them, to Adolf, to Hermann, to Joseph, to Baldur, and now Albert,  So, let's hear the truth, let's come clean. What was your Party number?
It would be truer to say, I think, that a lot of people in high places knew me.
You sure knew a lot of people in high places.

During an enforced hour-long interval because of a power failure at a concert here in Berlin, Albert Speer, the Minister of Armaments, said to me, 'You look very tired Dr. Furtwngler, you should go abroad for a while.' I knew exactly what he meant.
So, how did you learn that the Gestapo was out to get you?
You didn't complain about the racial policies, just about the musical standards, is that right?
I believe it was because of another letter I'd written to Goebbels lamenting the decline of musical standards due to racial policies.
Why were they going to arrest you?
It was because I learned that the Gestapo was about to arrest me.
I don't know, he wasn't my case. Why did you escape to Switzerland just before the war ended?

Then why is it, please, that another conductor who was actually a member of the Party, who used to play the Horst Wessel before his concerts, has already been cleared and is working again while I have to wait and wait and wait?
Tough, tough!
I need to work. I need to make my living. I live off the generosity of friends...
Your guess is as good as mine.
When will my case be heard by the Tribunal?
Sure.
May I ask a question?
Or maybe you called Goebbels or Goering? You were so close you were in the same shithouse as them.

Let me me help you, then. You picked up the phone and made a call -  'Hello, Adolf? Wilhelm speaking. Listen, old pal, there's a Jew-boy musician I want you to help. He needs a permit to get to Paris.'
I may have, as... as I said, I simply don't remember.
Did you call someone you knew?
I don't remember in detail, there were so many.
I keep hearing you helped a lot of Jews to escape. How did you do that?
It's the truth.
I don't buy that.
I made no deal!
Could I have a glass of water, please? Please, Fraulein?
How come?
That... that was a different matter, I... I was tricked.

That sounds like the small print in one of our insurance policies, Wilhelm. And what about April 19, 1942?  The eve of Hitler's fifty- third birthday, the big celebration; you conducted for Hitler, didn't you? Was that in keeping with your view that art and politics have nothing to do with each other?
I did not conduct at at the rally, I conducted on the evening before the rally.
Then why did you conduct at one of their Nuremberg rallies?

Well, there was a constant battle between Goering and Goebbels as to which of them would control German culture. I was simply a pawn. Anyway, I resigned from the Musikkammer at the same time I resigned as Musical Director of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. In 1934.

Goebbels and Goering were sure heaping honours on you. One makes you a Privy Councillor, the other makes you Vice-President of the Chamber of Music, and you weren't even a member of the Party, how do you explain that?
I don't think Dr. Goebbels sent me a telegram. I was simply told. In a letter, I believe. I don't remember exactly.

What about Vice-President of the Chamber of Music, you used that title didn't you? But then I suppose you had no choice there either, because I suppose Dr. Goebbels just sent you a telegram saying, Dear Mr. Vice-President.

I received a telegram from Hermann Goering informing me that he had made me a Privy Councillor. I was not given the opportunity either to accept or refuse. After the dreadful events of November 1938, the violent attacks on the Jews, I stopped using the title.
Could you tell us about being made a Prussian Privy Councillor. How did that happen to a non-Party member?
That is correct.

What they do in Austria doesn't interest me one little bit. Okay? I have your questionnaire here,  Gustav Heinrich Ernst Martin Wilhelm Furtwngler, born Berlin, January 1886. Orchestral conductor. And you say here you were never a member of the Nazi Party.
I have already been cleared by a Denazification Tribunal in Austria.

I want you to understand why you're here. You're automatically banned from public life under Control Council Directive No 24. We're here to look into your case before you appear in front of the Tribunal for Artists of the Denazification Commission. You understand that?
His private life?
And ask him about his private life.
Yes, yes you may notice that he cannot even bring himself to utter his name, he... he refers to him as K.
The Miracle Kid.

Also a conductor. Very brilliant. Young. Von der Null called him 'The Miracle von Karajan'. Furtwngler was outraged and they say he had von der Null conscripted into the army. The same thing happened to another critic. True or not, it's not such a bad idea. Critics give you bad reviews, you have them sent to the Russian front.  But if you really want to get Furtwngler, ask him about Herbert von Karajan.
Who's he?
Edwin von der Null. Music critic. He gave Furtwngler terrible reviews while he raved about Herbert von Karajan.
Never heard of him, who is he?
There's a rumour... I don't know if it's true or not... but ask him about von der Null.

No. But that's why we hated him. We admired him as a conductor but we all hated him too because he didn't have to join the Party and yet he had a better life than any of us. He didn't have to go and deliver a report after every trip abroad. He got everything from them, everything. He was filthier than any of us Party members.
But I need documentary proof. You know of anything like that?
Son-of-a-gun. We'll find the corporal and we'll find the telegram.
Yes. A corporal. US Army. A Jew. He said he'd seen the telegram in the Chancellery.
One of my people?
One of your people told me.
He did?
Furtwngler sent Hitler a telegram for his birthday.
Yeah?
I've remembered something else...
Of course. You, too. Like everyone else in this goddamn country.
The only thing I know is he's an anti-Semite.

Fuck that, Helmuth. You want to discuss symbols here?  This guy was a front man. He was the piper, but he played their tune, you get my philosophical meaning?  I'm not interested in small fish, I'm after Moby Dick. Come on, Helmuth. Hard facts.
Major, we're discussing a man of genius, I don't want...
I can give you freedom of movement, freedom to work, freedom, Helmuth. But I need something in return.
You don't know what it's like to wake up every single morning of your life terrified, you don't know that -
Oh, I see, he made you co-operate. And now are you a communist again?
I was a member of the Communist Party. I was a communist. That's what Hinkel had over me. He knew everything. He held that over me. That's how he made me co-operate.
Was a member of...?  Speak up?
One-zero-four-nine-three-three- one. Or d'you mind if I just call you 'one'?
What?
All in the cause of humanity, Helmuth. Or should I call you one- zero-four-nine-three-three-one?
You usually don't work on Sunday, Major?
So. You wanted to see me.
Great catch, kid. The boy runs off.
Don't worry, Helmuth, it'll be our secret.
Exactly.  Replaces the baton, gives Steve the case.
And I see what you mean. You nearly poked my eyes out.
Do it, Helmuth.
Not here, Major, there are people, if anybody should see... please, please, Major...
Yeah, show me, I want to see you do it. Pretend I'm Adolf. You're the maestro, and you have the baton in your right hand, but you give me the salute just the same.
Show you?
Show me.
How could I forget?
Yes, you remember.
The one he kept in his right hand. Yes, you remember.
It's Dr. Furtwngler's baton, which I stole.
Love 'em, Helmuth. I give up. What are you holding in your hand?
Guess what I am holding in my hand. You like guessing games?
Helmuth.
Major.
How could I know what's in the archive?
Do you know what's in this archive?
I hear the British have his... his archive, files, records.
Hans Hinkel was in the Ministry of Culture; how could I know such a man?  I
You seem to understand the question, now how about answering it?
Do I know Hans Hinkel?
That's what I asked.
Do I know Hans Hinkel?
Do you know Hans Hinkel?
Oh, we didn't play for his birthday, we played the evening before - it was the 19th of April not the 20th.
Excuse me. Did you know that he refused to give the Nazi salute when Hitler was present in the audience?
I'll ask the questions, Helmuth.
Is it true you're going to interview Dr. Furtwngler today?
Me? Never.  Never.
Good, and according to your questionnaire, Helmuth, you never joined the Nazi Party.
It means I wasn't good enough to be a first violinist.
Helmuth Alfred Rode. Second violinist since 1935. What's it mean, second violinist?
When you got to the crescendo.
I don't know what you mean, Major.
Was looking at Furtwngler like that?
Yes.
You ever seen Adolf Hitler's eyes when he was making a speech? I've seen 'em on films.

Politics and art must be kept separate. I'll remember that. But let me see if you can help me with something I just don't understand. I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about him. What's his secret?
Yes, Dr. Furtwngler was absolutely clear about this: politics and art must be kept separate.
Oh! The evening before, I see...
He was forced to do that. But he refused to give the Nazi salute in front of Hitler. He kept his baton in his hand, you can't salute with a baton in your hand.
But this was the same guy who conducted for Adolf on his birthday.
Goebbels, yes, Josef Goebbels said, 'There's not a single filthy Jew left in Germany on whose behalf Dr. Furtwngler has not intervened.' No, no one could have been less of a Nazi than Dr. Furtwngler.

Well, he's more than just a bandleader, Steve. He's a great conductor, a gifted artist. But we believe that he sold himself to the devil. Your number one priority from this moment on is to connect him to the Nazi Party. Don't be impressed by him. I want the folks back home to understand why we fought this war. Find Wilhelm Furtwngler guilty. He represents everything that was rotten in Germany.
Like this bandleader.

Well, they say here that when you went on a case, you stayed on it.  Now we can't take every Nazi in this country to trial, although I would like to; it's an impossibility. So we're going for the big boys in industry, education, law, culture.
They said I was dogged?
Conscientious, determined, dogged.
Right. Claims assessor.
You were in insurance before the war.
Jeez, and I never heard of him.
He's as big as Toscanini, maybe even bigger. In this neck of the woods, he's probably Bob Hope and Betty Grable rolled into one.
Sure.
Do you know who Arturo Toscanini is?
Nope.
So, you never heard of him.
Do you really think it was brave? Didn't he bow to him and shake his hand?
It was Beethoven's Ninth.
Brave?  To celebrate Hitler's birthday with some heroic piece by Wagner but without the Nazi salute? Bravo.
Yes, that's true, but he refused to give the Nazi salute. He kept his baton in his right hand. In Hitler's presence. That was a brave act...
He also conducted for Hitler, didn't he?
It was Hermann Goering. I was told he just made the maestro his Privy Councillor, no questions asked. Although Dr. Furtwngler stood up to him. And to Dr. Goebbels.
Then how do you explain him being made a Prussian Privy Councillor?
Dr. Furtwngler is a great musician. He actively opposed the Nazis and later on he helped many Jews to escape.
Hey, hey, slow up, Fraulein Straube has to take down what you say.
No, I was never a Nazi, I have no interest in politics, I'm a musician -
Absolutely not.
I have your questionnaire here. It says you were never a member of the Nazi Party.
First oboe.
Rudolf Otto Werner. Wind section since 1936. What instrument did you play?
Tremoille... don't.  Please...
What do you fear most now... my sword?  ... or his hands?
No.  I see the hand of Tremoille, and Regnault, and Yolande, and you... and they are dirty hands.

Jean... me dear, loyal Jean... why do you want to oppose the will of God?  Jeanne wanted to go to Compiegne -- we let her -- she got caught.  Then, on my personal orders, Regnault proposed 30,000 crowns for her ransom, and once again the answer was no.  And now you say she tried to escape, and the answer is still no.  Jean, open your eyes -- can't you see the hand of God in all this?
But not impossible... Gilles and La Hire are ready to risk everything to save her...
Jean, it's... it's not so easy...
We have to do something before she tries it again!  I beg of you, my lord, don't let her down... let me organize an escape...
It's a miracle she's not dead!
Jeanne's been badly injured!  She jumped from the top of a tower into a frozen moat!
My dear Aulon...  That's fine...
10,000 gold crowns.
Very generous of you all.  How much?
Here... to help pay Jeanne's ransom. All the Captains gave what they could, as well as the citizens of Orleans and the other towns she saved...
Yes, my lord.
Jeanne, this is -- in fact -- my loyal friend and finest archer, Jean d'Aulon.  Jean... I place her in your care.  Find her suitable lodgings -- here -- in the castle... and guard her with your life.
So... pretend it's not a game.
Sire, you know how bad I am at this sort of game.
Good.  Until then, feel free to live like a king!
Of course I am, it's just that...
Why, are you not ready to die for your king?
Majesty, I can't...
My dear Aulon, to you it shall befall the honor of impersonating the royal blood!
My lord, I'm not sure that...
Why not you -- Jean d'Aulon?  The only man who's poorer than I am, and so the only man I can trust. Dignified, honorable, wise... what more could we ask of a king?
... if she can find me? -- That's a brilliant idea!  If she's really been sent by God she'll discover the trap, and if she's an assassin she'll kill the wrong man!  Bring her up!
Let someone else pretend to be you, and see if...
What do you mean?
That's a good idea, sire.
Oh dear, why is life so complicated? Sometimes I really wish I could be someone else.
Jeanne, you can't leave us like this!
I'm not afraid of the fire anymore. It will purify me...

No, you must come, Jeanne -- we need you -- so much has happened since you left... I have a new horse now, a white one, just like yours... and La Hire hardly swears at all anymore...  You can't stay -- they'll burn you!
I'm staying, Jean.
... and maybe the king will give you some money, and a little land, and a title even...  ... wouldn't that be a fine thing? You, a lady of title!
You don't know what you're saying. You're going to leave this place, Jeanne -- you're going home -- or whatever you want -- you're going to be happy, and have children, and...
One day you will.
I -- I don't understand...
My gentle Captain... I'm staying.
Yes yes... any moment... you're always so impatient...
I'm already free...
Just give me a moment and then you'll be free...
I am ready now...
That's an order!
I want to stay with you...
Do as I say!
But... why... what's the point?
Get back inside the town and see if the English are attacking from the other side!
Not yet!
We must sound the retreat!
It would not be the same without you.
Will you at least let me stay with you?
If God wants me to win, he will find a way.  And if he wants me to die... if he wants me back... then that's fine too.  Then I'll be with him forever.
To be killed in battle?
But it is what I want.
But... you've done so much for God as it is... can't you do something for yourself for once -- for Jeanne?
I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God.
Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me.
Jeanne... I have been hearing voices -- and believe me, those voices left me in no doubt that you must not go to Compiegne!
I will ask my voices... if they come back one day.  Meanwhile... I'm going to Compiegne.
To marry you.
Did you come back to marry me or to insult me?
Or maybe it's Jeanne who's in a trap -- her own trap -- a downward spiral that she can't stop?
No, but...
Did your voices tell you that?  You told me you hadn't heard them for months...
It's a trap!  They're buying time till they can bring over more soldiers from England!
He said that... he's making a treaty with the Duke of Burgundy and...
What did the king say?
You listen to your voices, I listen to my heart.
That's not what I asked... Why do you want to marry me?
Tell the king to give me more men.
Tell me...
If you really want to help me, there's one thing you can do.
Jeanne... I believe in you... more than anyone...
So... even you don't believe in me anymore...

Me?!  It's not me, it's God who makes everything complicated!  If he's all-powerful, why not let the English stay on their island in the first place?  And why let this war go on for a hundred years?  And why send you out to fight when a girl like you should be at home with your family?  Why, why?!
The truth is always simple... it's you, Jean, who's making things complicated.
You make it sound so simple...
I don't know it.  I feel it.
But how do you know what you hear is the truth?
All you have to do is stop talking and just listen.
But I hear so many voices... one voice saying one thing, another voice saying the opposite -- love your enemy, kill your enemy -- what is good, what is evil...?
Well of course they're me!  That's how God talks to me.  If you listen hard enough, even you can hear him. Everyone can hear him.
But how do you know that these -- these voices aren't really just -- well, you.
It's not time yet.  My mission is not over yet.  There is still more I must do before I can really -- finally -- go home.
Maybe their silence is a sign...? Maybe it's a sign to go home?
It's been weeks since they spoke to me.  Since the coronation... no signs... nothing...
What... what do you mean?
They've abandoned me... like everyone.
So... what am I supposed to do now?
Jeanne... the king has ordered us not to ride with you anymore.
Because there's an arrow in your leg.
Yes.  Yes, I'm fine...  We need more brushwood!  Why are you staring at me like that?
Jeanne...!  Are you alright?
Jeanne, no...
I'll go.
It's over, Jeanne.  We won, just as you said!
Yes...
Jeanne, calm down, do you hear me? Are you alright?
Come with me...
Well...
The king said you're his finest archer...?
I promise...
Alright... I promise to rest if you promise... to go back to the battle.
No, it's... it's nothing, it's...
Jeanne, you've been badly wounded...
Not so... easily.  Why aren't you... fighting...?  go on... we're almost there...
They've started the battle without me!
What's going on?!
But... to be honest... I don't think they'll leave tomorrow.
Good.
Uh... they said... they will think about it.
What did they say?
Alright, whatever -- but since He's not going to come down and cut it himself, at least let someone cut it properly!
How dare you tell me what God tells me to do!
He didn't tell you to cut all your hair off...!
How dare you stop me doing God's will!
Jeanne, stop it!
There's nothing to hear -- I haven't done anything.  And why haven't I done anything?  Because none of you will listen to me!!
Jeanne, calm down.  You can't blame the people -- they've been hearing all about you for weeks.
Who do they think I am?!
The King of England.  I want to give them the chance to leave Orleans in peace before I get there.
Yes, I am.  I'm an archer who can read and write.  Who do you want to write to?
I thought you were an archer?
This I can do.  I was studying at the University of Paris -- till the English invaded it.
I also need someone who can read and write.
Well... uh -- this might take a little time -- but let me see what I can do.
Better today than tomorrow.
Now?
I shall also be needing a war horse -- mine is too slow -- and armor -- and a good sword -- and an artist to make me a banner.
Right.  Raymond... a priest.
Yes.  I didn't confess today.
Now?
And I would like to see a priest.
Louis... water and fresh straw!
I would like some fresh straw.
Do you think I could have some water?
Listen, please accept my apologies for... you know, me pretending to be the... well it wasn't really my idea... well, yes it was my idea but...

I'm fed up with taking her orders. She swore she'd defeat the English before nightfall, instead of which she goes and plays the fool and gets herself nearly killed!  Look at the mess we're in!  That's her mess, not mine...!  We're worse off then if she'd never come at all!  ... now do as I say and Sound the Retreat!
But that was her order!
I made no such promise.  Sound the retreat for the night!
But I promised Jeanne we'd fight on!
Sound the retreat...
We have to press home the attack!
Good.
Jeanne's alive!
No, I... I never killed anyone!

... so you were in the middle of the battlefield, with your sword in your hand, waving it above your head... charging against the enemy, screaming and yelling... fighting for your life... and you want us to believe that in the middle of all this excitement you never killed anyone?
Yes, maybe... I don't remember...
You held up your sword and flourished it about in the air? Like this?
No, I... I held it up to...
Did you use the sword that you held in your hand?
Yes, but...
So sometimes you were carrying just your sword?
Yes, probably... maybe...
We have numerous witnesses who can confirm that you were not always carrying your banner...
No!  I warned the English to go back home -- I begged them not to force us to fight -- they knew the defeat I would bring on them... why didn't they listen to me?
Then perhaps the temptation to kill would have been stronger... too strong perhaps...?
No, of course not... I never killed anyone...
Are you saying that if you had not been carrying your banner you'd have killed more people?
To avoid killing anyone.
Why?
And so I... I prefer my banner.
And?
No, it's just... a sword is a weapon.
And why was that?  Did it have some particular value or power?
I was forty times more fond of my banner than my sword.
Which did you prefer, your banner or your sword?
Yes...
Didn't you also carry a banner?
Quite a few.
Do you have a sword?
I leave the answer to God.
Ah, yes, I forgot... God sent us an illiterate peasant to carry out such an important mission!  Do you think that God made the right decision, to take an ignorant girl to save the kingdom of France?
I can't read.
That is not what is written in the evidence... look for yourself!
No... I said "Surrender in the name of the King of France"...
And didn't you order the citizens of Paris to surrender the city in the name of the King of Heaven?
I don't know...
Do you think is was a good idea to launch an attack on a holy day?
I don't remember.  Maybe.
It was on a Sunday, wasn't it?
I tried to.
Is it true that you launched an attack on Paris?
I don't know, but you're all men of the church... why not ask Him yourself?
Good advice for the French, not for the English!  Do you think God hates the English?
Go onto the next question.
No.  But my revelations were for the King of France, not for you.
Did God forbid you to tell the truth?
No...
You're afraid of displeasing God when telling the truth?!
I won't tell you more about that. I'm more afraid of displeasing Him than not answering you...
Performing a miracle.
W-w-what are you doing?!
No no, you don't understand -- this is no ordinary oil -- this is miraculous... this oil was brought from heaven by a white dove to crown King Clovis in this... very... cathedral...
Thirty years ago?  I'm not surprised it's gone...
Well... at the coronation of King Charles VI...
And when was that?
I don't understand... the holy oil of Clovis... it was quite full the last time I saw it...

Oh yes, my lady.  All true kings of France must first be anointed in our great cathedral of Rheims... with the holy oil of Clovis... for it was within these very walls that Saint Remy received the sacred oil from Heaven, brought to him by a white dove for the anointing of King Clovis...
It is the sacred place that matters, Charles -- not the size.  Am I correct, Bishop?
Well find some other way!  Be creative.  Tell them she fucks the devil... Hmm, not a bad idea... why can't you say that?  Sounds good to me... and who can prove she doesn't?
I'm on the side of our Mother Holy Church.  Besides, a confession under torture will never convince anyone of her guilt.
Whose side are you on, Cauchon?
Scared to make a mistake.  Supposing she's right... supposing she really has been sent by God??
Scared of a girl?
You won't be able to drag anything from her that way.  You also must realize that many of my colleagues are... well, scared...
Well what are you waiting for? You've got a castle full of racks and ropes and pulleys:  go and torture the bitch!
But we can't do that unless she admits to blasphemy...
... and your prerogative is to find her guilty...
It is not for us to burn her, my lord.  That is your prerogative.

So long as this bitch remains alive, our armies refuse to fight!  Don't you understand?  They want proof that God is on their side... and the only way they're going to believe that is when they see her being burnt as a witch!
Be patient, my lord... you've seen how it is.  This girl has a way with people... but everyday we're making progress...
How can I calm down when I'm made the laughing-stock of the whole court?!  I've had enough!
Calm down, my lord, I beg you!
Well then?  Start proving... or else the church will have another martyr!
But in order to do so, the church must first prove her heresy, or else you'll be burning a martyr...
We want her burned as a witch!
But if this trial seems fixed, I fear you'll have the very opposite result to the one you want...
To hell with procedure!  We paid a bloody fortune for this slut, and we can do whatever the hell we like with her, whether the church likes it or not -- is that clear?
I understand your impatience, but if you want this trial to be acknowledged as legal we must follow correct procedure and...
She's loyal to her king... it's only to be expected that she...
Who's running this trial, you or her?  I can't believe it!  This wretched girl -- how dare she speak to us like that?
Rouen is in English territory.  I have the right to do anything I like.  Take them away.
What are you doing?  This is an ecclesiastical court -- you have no right to do this!
Arrest them!
And God who allowed you to be caught?
God defeated the English, not me.

Your king?  Ah yes, of course... What's he going to pay me with? Cows?  Chickens?  I prefer gold, and the English have plenty.  I wonder how much they'll pay... to have the Witch of Orleans in their clutches? Those English are so arrogant, they can't accept the idea of being defeated by a peasant girl... it has to have been the devil's work.
My king will pay any ransom you ask.
Guess.
Where... where am I?
Dead you're worthless, darling.
Am I... am I dead?
So... here is the famous Jeanne... Savior of Orleans... terror of the English?  You look pretty ordinary to me...
I'll be right here... I promise.
But where are you going to be?
Don't worry about me -- just stay in here... and don't move!
What about you?
Quick -- hide in here...
I was talking to the priest, and do you know what he said to me?
Really?
I was so worried -- we've all been looking for you!  The English are everywhere!  O thank you, lord!
No no, I'm fine, really...
Are you alright?  Did they hurt you?
I -- I can't Jeanne... I can't hear your confession... I'm sorry...
I ask only one thing... to hear me in confession...
It's not my body I want to save. It's my soul.
I know, Jeanne... it was the only way to save you from the fire!
And you?  Why did you lie?  You promised I could be confessed...
I don't understand, Jeanne... why did you do it?  Why?
Silence her!  Take her away...!
I didn't mean it!  I didn't know what I was signing!  You tricked me...!
You have nothing to regret...
Please... may I have it back...
As often as you like -- now, please -- for the love of God -- sign!!
And may I go to Mass?
Sign this, and I will confess you myself if you want.
No... I want to be confessed.
Jeanne, I beg of you... sign!  In God's name, don't you understand? I'm trying to save you!  If you don't sign, the English will burn you to death!  Is that what you want??
I am sent by God, and I submit all my words and deeds to His judgment. Or do you think that you are better judges than He is?
It is for us to determine whether you are a good Christian, not you.
So it is the Church Militant that refuses to confess me, and so prevents me from being a good Christian?

Let me clarify things for you, Jeanne.  On the one hand there is the Church Triumphant, that is to say God, his saints, and the souls that are saved.  And then there is the Church Militant, that is to say our Holy Father the Pope, the cardinals, the prelates of the Church, the clergy, and all good Catholic Christians.  Moreover this Church, when assembled, is guided by the Holy Spirit and therefore cannot be in error.  That is why we ask you to submit to the Church Militant... that is to say, us.
Is it here?  Now?  In this room?
Yes...
Tell us, Jeanne... do you often hear this voice?
Did it give you advice?  Good advice?
Many things...
What did it tell you?
Yes.
The voice was in your cell?
Praying.
What were you doing when the voice came?
Last night.
When exactly?  A day, a week -- when?
Not long ago...
I assure you they do.  So... answer me... when was the last time you heard this voice?
These questions have nothing to do with your trial.
Jeanne, you are not helping yourself.  If you don't answer our questions properly, your refusal will be taken into account.
And you be careful, you who claim to be my judges, for you too will be judged one day...!
Jeanne -- be careful -- you're not helping yourself by refusing to submit to our judgment...
Not unless you hear my confession.

Jeanne, listen to me very carefully. We are all men of faith, and we shall earnestly strive for the salvation of both your soul and body as though it were our own.  We do so in the name of our Holy Mother Church, who never closes her arms to those who would return to her.  But we cannot help you unless you submit to our learned judgment and authority.  Take heed of this charitable admonition, for if you persist in refusing our help, then we shall have no choice but to abandon you to the secular powers, and I think you know well enough the punishment that would await you.  So now... will you please recite Our Lord's Prayer?
Not unless you hear my confession.
Recite the Lord's Prayer.
Yes.  In the church at Domremy.
Were you baptized?
Nineteen... or thereabouts...
How old are you?
In a village called Domremy.
Show us a little more cooperation first.  Where were you born?
My name is Jeanne.  My little cross I had round my neck was taken away from me.  I would like to have it back.
So... begin by telling us your name -- assuming you're allowed to tell us that much?
I will willingly swear to tell you what I am allowed to tell you, but as to the rest, even if you threaten to cut off my head, I still won't tell you.
You must take the oath!  Not even a king, would refuse to take an oath to tell the truth in a matter of faith.
I will willingly swear to tell the truth about earthly things, but as for my revelations, I've never told anyone except my king... Charles the Seventh... the one and only king of France.
You will swear to tell the truth about whatever you are asked.
I don't know what you're going to ask me questions about.  You may ask things that I won't want to answer.
Take the Holy Gospels in your hand and swear to tell the whole truth concerning everything you will be asked.
Yes.  They paid your ransom... tomorrow you will be transferred to their great castle at Rouen.
The English??
It seems that the English care more about you than the French.
But... the King -- my king -- didn't he pay my ransom?
Your trial, Jeanne.  On a charge of heresy.
Trial?  What trial??
Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais. As you were captured in my diocese, the duty of conducting the trial falls upon me.
Who are you?
I will hear you... but not now, not here.
Oh, thank you Lord!  I'm so glad to see you!  I need to confess... I haven't been confessed since Easter... or been to Mass... Will you hear me now?
Don't look at the cost, look at what it brings.  What is your last offer?
20,000?!  But... I heard King Charles was... financially embarrassed.
I understand.  How much?

This word is -- regrettably appropriate for the situation.  In fact what we -- the Church -- wish to do is determine whether or not this girl is sent by God, as she claims.  You understand that we cannot allow just anybody to abuse God's name in this manner...
Buying her?
Not so well, I regret to say.  This business with the Maiden... it's caused him endless grief and torment.  That's why he's entrusted me with the task of... shall we say...
And your Duke?  The Duke of Bedford?
Thanks be to God.
He's feeling wonderful.
Good day, sir.  I trust my honorable Duke of Burgundy is feeling well?
Then her faith will have to be bigger.
But... her army's so small now...

Don't worry, Charles.  If God is still with her, she will be victorious.  We're not her judges... we're just spectators.  Let her go to Compiegne, as you let her go to Orleans, and let God decide her fate.
I... I can't stop her.

I assure you, Charles, the Maiden has no greater admirer than myself. But whatever our personal feelings, we cannot allow her to conduct her own private war.  For the sake of the kingdom, it is imperative that you stop her going to Compiegne...
It's true.  There's only one king... people need to be reminded of that. Nevertheless... Jeanne has done so much for us...
For the sake of France, Charles. And for the sake of my grandson.
You will??

You're a fine judge of character, Charles.  It'll take you less than five minutes to expose her if she's a fake.  But if she's not -- then she will give you your answers... and place the crown on your head.
You really think she's been sent... by God?
Who better than a messenger from God to give answers to your questions?
W-w-what has that got to do with this Maiden?
Mmmm.  Yes.  I know for example the sickness that plagues your heart.  I know how painful it is for you... to have loved a father... without ever knowing if he really was yours.
You think?
Your health and happiness has always been my first concern, Charles... ever since you were a little boy -- and I think I know you better than your own mother...
Why do you have to be so bloodthirsty?  Do you enjoy it?  All that blood and noise and pain? Diplomacy is far more civilized... far safer... and far cheaper...
Peace will only be got from the English at the end of a lance!

Well... we are, of course, enormously grateful for your past efforts, but your task is done.  Now it's time for negotiation... and after many months of skillful work, our dear Tremoille is about to seal a treaty with our Burgundian friends who will no longer lend their support to the English.  You see, my dear Jeanne... as it is written in the Bible, "to everything there is a season:  a time for war, and a time for peace"...
So how would you put it?
Gave you?  Well now, I wouldn't quite put it like that...
Why did you betray me?  Paris was ours for the taking!  All I needed was another few hundred men... Why did you take back the army you gave me?
Now hold on -- you're not captain here... on the battlefield perhaps, but not in the royal bedchamber!
Get them out of here!
... and my crown doesn't fit and...  Really??
... You look wonderful...
Ah, Jeanne... come here...!  This whole coronation idea of yours is a fiasco... nothing is ready...
Orleans has held out for six months. I don't suppose a few days will make much difference.  Take some rest.
I don't need lodgings if we're to be marching on Orleans...
He said that I have to save France from her enemies and give her back to God, and He told me that I -- Jeanne -- will lead you to the altar at Rheims to be crowned King of France.
... and what... what did he say?
I didn't wait long.  One day I was going to Mass, like I do every day, when the same strange wind started blowing again...
You did well...
What was my mission?  To help my country?  But how could I do that? I was only a poor girl who knew nothing about riding or making war... so I decided to wait and not to speak to anyone about it.
I know you're not yet -- but you will be, soon.
I'm... I'm not the king...
There's no need to be afraid, sire.
Noooo!
I... I don't know... it'll sound like we... betrayed her...?
Let them come!  Let them see who's the true king of France!
There's no time, sire -- we can't hold up the ceremony... there's no telling when the English might come back... they're only ten leagues away...
He's probably right -- let's call a delay...
No doubt your captains will fight for your fine cause -- but what about the ordinary soldier?  They don't fight for causes these days. They fight for money.  Who's going to pay them?
My captains have sworn their support.
... to ensure our privacy.  I need to talk to her.  Alone.
... as always, majesty...
My dear loyal Tremoille, I know I can count on you...
Your majesty, I really think you...
Tremoille, I'm not even king yet... who'd want to assassinate me?
Supposing she's an assassin?
My astrologers assure me that the hour is p-p-propitious -- Leo, with Virgo rising.  Have you ever noticed on the astrological chart how the Virgin is next to the Lion?
Your majesty, I urge you not to see this woman.  It all reeks of a Burgundian trap!
The other half.
I can see her if I want to.  I mean, with half of France in the hands of the English, what have I got to lose?

Not exactly.  She wants you to give her an army -- at your expanse.  Bearing in mind that your mother stole every last piece of gold in the treasury, I fail to see how you can afford such an adventure.
If she comes from Burgundy it makes a difference.  It might be a trap...  Look... Signed "X".  What sort of name is "X"?  Or must we conclude that a messenger of God can't even write her own name?
What difference does it make where she comes from?
You mustn't see her, my lord.  We know nothing about her... we don't even know if she is from Lorraine.
She says she'll be here tomorrow...!
She pretends she's been sent by God! These charlatans -- it's a pity there isn't enough wood to burn them all!
That's enough!  You will answer the question... or face the consequences!
Go on to the next question.
But if the devil were to take on the physical appearance of a saint or an angel... or a man... how would you recognize him?  By what he said?
I'm more interested in what he says, not what he looks like.
Is it long and hanging down?
Yes.
Does he have hair?
His face.
You told us about the appearance of this... voice.  What exactly did you see?  Part of it... or all of it?
Go and ask him yourself.
Then why did your king believe in you without any proof?
If there was, I didn't see it...
When you saw your king for the first time, was there an angel over his head?
I must offer to the Duke.  I will give you his answer tomorrow.
8,000.  We can't raise more... We can only place ourselves at the mercy of your generosity.
20,000 gold crowns.
May I, without offending you, inquire how generous?
I know... but the English want her very badly, and I have to tell you that they are proving much more generous.
It is all his majesty can afford. He has even donated his very own personal savings.  His majesty will greatly appreciate a gesture of good will in this delicate negotiation between our two families.
That's not a lot.
5,000 gold crowns.
The English won't wait.
Not yet.
Well...?  Shall we go?
The bridge won't wait!
We need another ten minutes...
Stand by with the battering-rams...
I know what I'm doing, so either lend a hand or go back to bed!
Jeanne, what are you doing with that... you've got it back to front...
We're taking back the Tourelles!
What's going on?
The wind will be with us!  Do as I say.
The wind will be against us...
Position the long-bows over there, crossbows over there -- and set up Dijon Culverins either side of those trees...
Sooner is better than later!
Can we -- uh -- discuss this later?
Dunois... was it you who ordered the attack?  Answer me?!
Knowing what I know?  Enormous gratitude.
Jeanne, put yourself in my shoes for a moment -- how would you feel, if you were me?
Ah, so that's it.  To you I'm just a girl.
Jeanne, you have to understand -- it's not easy for us -- I mean for our pride -- to suddenly be usurped by a -- well, with all due respect, by a... girl.
Be patient, be patient... is that the only advice you can ever come up with??  I've shown more patience than a dozen saints!

What complicated about it?  All you have to do is do what you're told -- what could be simpler than that? I'm the drum on which God is beating out his message -- beating so loudly it's bursting my ears -- but you're all so full of your own voices, you're deaf to His!
Jeanne, with respect -- we can't just attack the Tourelles like that -- it's a very complicated matter and...
You know, I feel a great sorrow for you, because you're laughing now, but by tomorrow night some of you will be dead and having to repeat your jokes in front of God.
God.

Jeanne, that really makes no sense at all.  The Tourelles is virtually impregnable... besides, if we're on the other side of the river attacking the Tourelles, what's to stop Talbot attacking the city from the north?
We offer the English a last chance to return home in peace.  If they refuse, we recross the river and attack them here -- at the Tourelles.
So... what is the message?

Fine -- go now if you want, but not with me!  You may have a duty to God but I have a duty to my people, and my people are starving!  So right now I'm going to take the food back to the city, and if you can please calm down, and let me accompany you to Orleans, it will be my honor to welcome you.
You may have been with your counsel, but I've been with mine, and I'm telling you, God's counsel is wiser than yours, and he's telling me to speak to the English -- now!

Well.  I'd love to see that, but after taking counsel with my captains, I felt it would be better to first bring the food into the city, then wait till Alencon arrives with reinforcements before doing anything.
Because if they don't, I'll raise such a war-cry against them that they will remember us forever!

Because... because -- I mean -- the English have a broad sense of humor, but... I mean, you don't understand... to them you're a witch, working for the devil.  What makes you think they'll listen to you?
For what?
Wait, wait...
He's on the other side of the river.
Good.  Can you bring me to him?
I know...
It's coming -- I rode on ahead.  I have to speak with the Captain of the English army... his name's Talbot...
Everywhere.  Where is the food?
Good.  Where are the English?
Yes... they were.
Were you sent by Lord Dunois?
As long as she brings food and supplies, she'll be welcome.
But... don't you think we should at least... go and... welcome her?
Xaintrailles...!  Don't talk to me about miracles...  If I was still sitting there waiting for a miracle, I'd be dead now. Anyway...
And it's not the first one!  They say she saved a little boy who was dying of...
Yes, it's a miracle.
The Dauphin -- he's sending us food -- and supplies -- and an army -- led by Jeanne -- the maiden from Lorraine -- isn't it wonderful?!
